As we learn at the beginning of this 91 minute documentary - another fine release from the Cohen Media Group - in 1931 there were 1,500 Jewish deli's in the five boroughs of NY. In 2014 there  are just 150 such delis in the WHOLE United states. And, unlike what you'd expect - at least I did - many currently operating delis (nearly all run by 2nd or 3rd generation "deli men" (though there is one "deli woman") are NOT in NY. They are Chicago, Houston, Toronto, San Francisco and Boca Raton, FL

Most of the story is told by visits to, and interviews with, various deli owners. The one who gets the most screen time - and is one of the most interesting - is Ziggy Gruber from Houston, TX. There is also a side-story about Ziggy's love life that is fun to follow.

There are a few "deli celebrities here" Larry King and Jerry Stiller.

If you aren't hungry by the time you start watching this, you will be by the end. You'll learn a lot of "deli lore" (who created the first "huge sandwich"?).
There are 40 minutes of interview outtakes, some comments from deli-maven Allan Dershowitz and a visit to the famous ACME Smoked Fish company. Nearly an hour of extra material which is not on the Streaming Amazon Instant version.

I guess at points, I felt the film got repetitive but I did enjoy it all the way through and glad I did get to see it.

Like most other Cohen  releases this includes a color 8-page booklet . This time it is  mostly photos plus a few production credits. No essay or other text.

I hope you found this review both informative and helpful.

Steve Ramm

"Deli Man" or "Deli Men"?  The documentary features around a dozen or so third generation+ family guys, but one is prominently featured enough to claim the title "Deli Man".  That is Mr. "Ziggy" Gruber, who while he can't be called "The Confuscious of Corned Beef" (that name was already taken), he has got to be the closest equivalent to the "soup nazi" from Seinfeld you have ever seen.  He KNOWS how to cook this food correctly, and while he is much more amicable than the soup nazi he is never-the-less driven by the same pure perfection.  A sentimental man with a passion for the past, he is part of a great story to be told that can make you happy and sad at the same time.

This documentary tries to be many things, and succeeds for the most part in all of them.  The history and origins of the American deli (actually German), the story of eastern european immigrants, jewish culture, the importance of food and family.  Ziggy gets the star treatment here, but you also get the sense that all the "deli operators" have equally good stories to tell and all share the same dedication. Grateful men and women who love food yes, and love to make money (or at least try), but first and foremost lovers of their communities who contribute to where they live through their restaurants.

That love is shared back by well known comedians such as Jerry Stiller and Feyvush Finkel, who give cameo commentary alongside other past New York stars on the historical importance of these delis.  4 1/2 stars only because it was a tad long and ever so slightly indulgent.  Like any true deli customer, you have to find something to complain about, right? Until the deli goes out of business one day and you realize no manner of a McDonaldized America can replace them.  Long live the deli!

What a great entrance!  Setting the tone is a lively Klezmer track, accompanying the crack-of-dawn delivery trucks at Kenny and Ziggy's Deli in Houston. Ziggy Gruber is a 3rd generation deli man, who began to learn his trade at 8, at the side of his beloved grandfather. So attached to him was Ziggy, that even his speech and cadence are more reminiscent of that generation than his own. He brings a heap of personality to the piece, as does the storytelling of many old-timers, including Jerry Stiller, Lary King, and Fyvush Finkel. The role of the deli and its interface with the Jewish population in religious and cultural events, across the life cycle, is impressive. But few delis have survived shifting demographics and extreme rises in cost of products and leases. Started by early Jewish immigrants who arrived with little more than the delicious recipes of their families and ancestors, kosher delis in 1931 numbered 1500, just in New York's 5 burroughs. Today there are 150 nationwide. So the deli man, for the love of it, perseveres in this physically, emotionally, and financially challenging environment. The food shots might stimulate a little drooling or growling. Winningly directed by Erik Anjou, with solid filming by David Sperling, and fine editing by Lisa Pallatella, this is a worthy one-- for Jews, and non-jews, and enthusiastic fans of culinary and cultural history.  Recommend.

An excellent film for both deli lovers and those that don't think about them much.  Director Erik Greenberg Anjou tracks the great winnowing of the classic Jewish delicatessen in America, from thousands of locations at the height of their popularity down to about 150 locations today.  Anjou gets nice little cameos from Jerry Stiller, Larry King, Alan Dershowitz and others (the great Fyvush Finkel is a standout).  The real standouts, however, are the deli owners themselves.  And, contrary to what you'd think, Anjou's leading man has set up shop in Houston, TX, not NYC.

Ziggy Gruber is a third-generation deli man and classically trained chef.  A native New Yorker, he landed in Houston.  He knows about delis and history.  He's the audience's guide and storyteller.  Without Ziggy, there's a far less interesting movie.

I liked that Anjou tried to focus on the newer generation of deli men.  Ziggy is a combination of the old and the new, but we also see the scions of the Canter deli in LA plus those trying to establish new traditions like Zane Caplansky with namesake Caplansky's in Toronto and Evan Bloom and Leo Beckerman, co-proprietors of Wise Sons in San Francisco

And that is a multitude of things but one important component which is that while Jews were blocked through often unjust circumstances from becoming lawyers/doctors/professionals when first arriving in the US, they were able to take their genius and incredible abilities and apply them to food. And when you take a genius - such as Ziggy, and have that brain focused on pastrami instead of quantum physics - you get something incredible - to eat! Spitting in the face of the Nazis and the Communists that chased these people all over, and eventually out of Europe - making them an essential part of the American experience. And so I liked that comment about walking back to Hungary, although what a miserable f-ing scene in that synagogue with that god-awful music.

I will also say that more than Jewish culture, the film celebrates what it means to be a New Yorker - as evidenced from the difference we see in the Canadian and Californian Delis (those lame losers with the socks on their head - tempura batter kugel or something - give me a break). I have to start out by saying I am biased.  I am Jewish and really enjoy reading about the lives of the immigrants who came to this country around the turn of the 20th century.  This documentary showed quite a lot about the history of that period through the telling of the story of the Jewish delicatessens.  Starting out as a place where the poor immigrants in New York could get a cheap meal of food they were comfortable with, the documentary showed the growth of the delis as the Jews started to become part of the main stream culture.
The delis they featured included several in New York City where I had eaten as well as Canter's in Los Angeles where I grew up.
I thought they did a good job of showing the rise (to over 1500 delis in New York city alone) to today's low of 150 in the entire country.
The comments from the older Jewish performers still around and the description of the stars whose pictures lined the walls of one of the famous delis added to my interest in the film.
As a history buff, I felt sorry for the people who gave this documentary low scores and said they were bored and watched only a few minutes of the film.  Knowing where many of our ancestors came from, the kind of environment they entered when they first arrived in the USA and how they eventually thrived should give us some idea of how our country became such a great melting pot.

I landed a job across the street from Carnegie Deli on Seventh Avenue, so I wanted to try out the famed deli that I had heard so much about throughout the years.

I had ordered at the counter a corned beef sandwich on rye and went to sit down. There were a few others already at the extended tables so I laid down my plate at an empty place and began to eat. Someone at the table, asked me to pass him the mustard. I did and replied "you're welcome." Before I knew it, I was surrounded  by tourists who wanted to see and talk to an original New Yorker, I grew up and lived in both the Bronx and Queens.

Before, I knew it, I had tourists to my left and to my right, all asking questions. To appease them, I switched over to my Robert DiNero, Woody Allen accent and talked jokingly to the tourists with my thick, Bronx nasal voice, playing the funny, tough guy. They were astounded, pleased, awed to be sitting next to a real New Yorker. I told them about living under the rumble of the Jerome Avenue line, and sloshing through the mud of Little Neck Bay.

When I finished eating and talking, I walked out of the deli, leaving the tourists wanting more. Upon feeling the fresh air, I went back to work.

A fun film with a lot of schamltz. "Deli Man" is a documentary by Erik Anjou and Erik Greenburg on the history and current state of Jewish delicatessen food in the United States. The film mainly centers around deli owner and chef David "Ziggy" Gruber who's a second generation "deli man." Who doesn't love a pastrami or corned beef piled high on rye? From what were hundreds of Jewish delis in New York alone (back in the 30s through the 50s) only a handful survive today. And an even smaller amount throughout the U.S. You've probably heard of them: Nate and Al's, Carnegie Deli, Cantor's, Stage Door, 2nd Avenue...Manny's in Chicago.
It's a tough business: the deli restaurant biz. It's not heart healthy. It's not vegan (c'mon, let's hear it for corned tongue). It's salty. Fatty. Smoked.
Okay, I'm hungry already.
But it's tradition. Something in today's fad-conscious society that's becoming a rarity. And "Ziggy" is the keeper of the flame.
It's kind of like Borscht Belt humor and Vaudeville, it's passé unless someone keeps it alive.
There's cameos by Larry King, Fyvush Finkel, Jerry Stiller, Freddie Roman and other Jewish comics. All lovers of deli food.
So grab a kosher dill, yellow mustard, and your favorite deli meat and savor the flavor. And may your matzos ball soup have plenty of chicken fat.

DELI MAN is a documentary that focuses on Ziggy Gruber, a co-owner of the biggest deli in Houston and grandson of one of the original big delis in New York years ago. Ziggy loves his business. He loves the tradition that hes carrying on. He loves the history of it all. And all of that shows not only in this film but in the business that he runs.

Keep in mind were not talking about that section of the grocery store that sells cold cuts and potato salad. Certainly their basis began with the real delis of old. What this movie is about are the outstanding delicatessens that have fallen by the wayside for the most part, dropping from the thousands to a mere handful in todays world of fast food menus. Delis of old created special sandwiches and carried items like matzo ball soup, served real meats that were cooked fresh and sliced to order and featured many kosher delicacies as well.

The movie might focus on Ziggy, coming back to him and his tale often but it also presents a pretty comprehensive history of the American deli at the same time. Through still of the past, old footage and interviews with deli customers and owners you get a timeline and a better understanding of what a deli actually was. It also makes you long for those delis to return in full force. Sure the local McD can make you a quick burger but the end product while passable will never have the same flavor of a corned beef on rye made on the spot rather than shipped frozen across country.

Watching this movie gave me hope. Its the same reason a show like DINERS, DRIVE-INS AND DIVES is so popular. People love food. But more than that they love real food at reasonable prices. They long for the places that used to dot the country from one end to the other, places that served fresh food to hungry customers, that recognized you when you walked in. Like to spots found on that series, delis offered the same thing.

Watching this movie you grow fond of Ziggy and want nothing but long lasting success for him and for his deli. You want him to find happiness and by the end it appears that he has. It will also make anyone who is able to do so want to take a trip to Houston just to stop in and sample what he offers. My guess is that those who are fortunate enough to do so will be glad they did. The movie presents an Oscar worth feature that covers the topic well and deserves notice.

We ate at Kenny & Ziggy's the other night, here in Houston.  As usual, their food was superb.  ZIggy was trained as a chef and it shows; it's not your grandmother's Jewish cuisine (which was very good, don't get me wrong).  But, it's that cuisine raised to a much higher standard.  Their sandwiches (pastrami, corned beef) are superb, of course.  But, they do all kinds of interesting dishes that used to exist in eastern European cuisine but have disappeared among American Jewish families (like stuffed cabbage and Kishka).  They also have a lot of innovative dishes such as quinoa salad (very tasty, but not very Eastern European).

Anyway, the film is terrific and deals with the evolution and virtual disappearance of Jewish delis in the U.S.  Apparently, there are only about 150 left.  Plus, of all the owners interviewed in the film, only Ziggy, a couple from Canter's in Los Angeles, and a couple of guys from San Franciso are youngish.  Unfortunately, it's a dying cuisine that is starting to be taken over by chain restaurants.  Sad.  But, as the film points, unlike, say, Italian, Chinese or Mexican restaurants, there aren't any Jewish immigrant cohorts from Eastern Europe coming in to replenish the traditional cultural restaurants; they were either wiped out by the Nazis or left Eastern Europe long ago. Going to a deli has unfortunately become like going to a museum to see the past.

As stated in the movie, the number of delis has declined dramatically. There is a reason for that. I was appalled at how the owner walks around while people are eating, interrupts them, and pushes them to talk to him. I also did not think the food looked too great either. I got about half way before I could no longer tolerate the pretentiousness of the whole thing.
